Award.AwardTitle: The Twentieth (20th) International Conference on Nucleation and Atmospheric Aerosols (ICNAA); Helsinki, Finland; June 25-30, 2017
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides travel support for graduate students and early career researchers to attend the 20th International Conference on Nucleation and Atmospheric Aerosols (ICNAA) that will be held in Helsinki, Finland in 2017. This support will allow these early career scientists an opportunity to share their research results and to interact scientifically with an international cross-section of experts in their fields. Advancing knowledge of the processes that form cloud particles will advance weather and climate research.

The International Conference on Nucleation and Atmospheric Aerosols focuses on the formation, physical and chemical properties, transformations, and cloud impacts of atmospheric aerosol particles. The conference is held every four years in rotating locations. The desired outcomes of the meeting are to strengthen the connections between the theoretical, modeling, and applications-based researchers from the international community and to foster the involvement of early career scientists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Participation in international conferences offers young scientists unmatched opportunities for sensing the pulse beat of scientific research, and evaluating the scientific merit of their own research, on a global scale. As well, there is a broader opportunity for developing their professional networks via face-to-face meeting with worldwide experts. The International Conference on Nucleation and Atmospheric Aerosols (ICNAA) was held in Helsinki, Finland during June 25-30, 2017. This conference is held only once every four years. It connects two research communities, those concerned with fundamental aspects of nucleation of all physical systems (how condensed phases first form), but with a slant on atmospheric particles, and atmospheric aerosol scientists working from the scales of new particle formation from gases to the interactions of natural and pollution particles with clouds. This proposal funded travel support for graduate students, postdoctoral scientists and scientists with special need to attend this conference.

The existence of travel awards was advertised broadly via websites of the Committee on Nucleation and Atmospheric Aerosols (visible via the International Union of Geophysics and Geodesy), American Geophysical Union, American Association for Aerosol Research, and the American Meteorological Society, as well as via distributed emails. Awards were based on the application form draft in our original proposal and review by the International Advisory Committee of the 20th ICNAA. The final form of travel awards for the 20th ICNAA consisted of award of airline costs, registration fees and housing stipends in various combinations ranging from $700 to $2200. Nine persons were supported from seven institutions across the United States. Of these, 5 awards were to graduate students, 1 to a postdoctoral scientist and 3 to researchers with special financial need for attending. All awardees expressed that their attendance would not have been possible without NSF support, yet all also sought and gained supplemental support from their institutions. 

Awardee presentations represented the full range of meeting topic areas. Seven of the award recipients presented oral presentations, one as a feature presentation outside of parallel sessions, and the two others at a very well-attended poster session that composed a 3-hour period during the conference. The ratio of oral presentations in the NSF award winners far exceeded the 40% oral distribution of all attendees, showing the strong scientific merit of the research presented by awardees who might not have otherwise had the opportunity to present their work.
